 356    def nuclear_rep_energy(self, mol=None):
 357        """
 358        Compute the nuclear-nuclear repulsion energy.
 359
 360        Parameters
 361        ----------
 362        mol : Molecule, optional
 363            Molecule object containing nuclear coordinates and charges. 
 364            If None, uses `self.mol`.
 365
 366        Returns
 367        -------
 368        float
 369            The nuclear repulsion energy in Hartrees.
 370        """
 371        # Nuclear-nuclear energy
 372        if mol is None: 
 373            mol = self.mol
 374    
 375        e = 0
 376        for i in range(mol.natoms):
 377            for j in range(i, mol.natoms):
 378                if (i!=j):
 379                    dist = mol.coordsBohrs[i]-mol.coordsBohrs[j]
 380                    e = e + mol.Zcharges[i]*mol.Zcharges[j]/np.sqrt(np.sum(dist**2))
 381
 382        return e
 383        
 384    # full density matrix for RKS/RHF
 385    def gen_dm(self, mo_coeff, mo_occ):
 386        """
 387        Generate the density matrix from molecular orbital coefficients and occupations.
 388
 389        Parameters
 390        ----------
 391        mo_coeff : ndarray
 392            Molecular orbital coefficient matrix.
 393
 394        mo_occ : ndarray
 395            Array of MO occupation numbers.
 396
 397        Returns
 398        -------
 399        ndarray
 400            Density matrix (RHF/RKS type).
 401        """
 402        mocc = mo_coeff[:,mo_occ>0]
 403   
 404        return np.dot(mocc*mo_occ[mo_occ>0], mocc.conj().T)
 405    
 406    def getOcc(self, mol=None, energy_mo=None, coeff_mo=None):
 407        """
 408        Assign occupation numbers to molecular orbitals based on their energies.
 409
 410        Parameters
 411        ----------
 412        mol : Molecule
 413            Molecule object to extract the number of electrons.
 414
 415        energy_mo : ndarray
 416            Array of MO energies.
 417
 418        coeff_mo : ndarray
 419            Array of MO coefficients (not used but kept for compatibility).
 420
 421        Returns
 422        -------
 423        ndarray
 424            Array of MO occupations (0 or 2 for RHF).
 425        """
 426        e_idx = np.argsort(energy_mo)
 427        e_sort = energy_mo[e_idx]
 428        nmo = energy_mo.size
 429        occ_mo = np.zeros(nmo)
 430        nocc = mol.nelectrons // 2
 431        occ_mo[e_idx[:nocc]] = 2
 432        return occ_mo
 433    
 434    def gen_dm_cupy(self, mo_coeff, mo_occ):
 435        """
 436        Generate the density matrix using CuPy for GPU acceleration.
 437
 438        Parameters
 439        ----------
 440        mo_coeff : cp.ndarray
 441            Molecular orbital coefficient matrix (on GPU).
 442
 443        mo_occ : cp.ndarray
 444            Array of MO occupation numbers (on GPU).
 445
 446        Returns
 447        -------
 448        cp.ndarray
 449            Density matrix (RHF/RKS type) computed on the GPU.
 450        """
 451        mocc = mo_coeff[:,mo_occ>0]
 452        return cp.dot(mocc*mo_occ[mo_occ>0], mocc.conj().T)
 453    
 454    def getOcc_cupy(self, mol=None, energy_mo=None, coeff_mo=None):
 455        """
 456        Assign occupation numbers to MOs using CuPy (for GPU-based calculations).
 457
 458        Parameters
 459        ----------
 460        mol : Molecule
 461            Molecule object to determine number of electrons.
 462
 463        energy_mo : cp.ndarray
 464            MO energy array on the GPU.
 465
 466        coeff_mo : cp.ndarray
 467            MO coefficients array on the GPU (not used).
 468
 469        Returns
 470        -------
 471        cp.ndarray
 472            Array of MO occupations (on GPU).
 473        """
 474        e_idx = cp.argsort(energy_mo)
 475        e_sort = energy_mo[e_idx]
 476        nmo = energy_mo.size
 477        occ_mo = cp.zeros(nmo)
 478        nocc = mol.nelectrons // 2
 479        occ_mo[e_idx[:nocc]] = 2
 480        return occ_mo
 481    
 482    def solve(self, H, S, orthogonalize=False, x=None):
 483        """
 484        Solve the generalized or canonical eigenvalue equation.
 485
 486        Parameters
 487        ----------
 488        H : ndarray
 489            Hamiltonian matrix.
 490
 491        S : ndarray
 492            Overlap matrix.
 493
 494        orthogonalize : bool, optional
 495            If True, solve using orthogonalized basis.
 496
 497        x : ndarray, optional
 498            Transformation matrix (if already computed).
 499
 500        Returns
 501        -------
 502        tuple of (ndarray, ndarray)
 503            Eigenvalues and eigenvectors of the system.
 504        """
 505        if not orthogonalize:
 506            #Solve the generalized eigenvalue equation HC = SCE
 507            eigvalues, eigvectors = scipy.linalg.eigh(H, S)
 508            
 509        else:
 510            if x is None:
 511                eig_val_s, eig_vec_s = scipy.linalg.eigh(S)
 512                # Removing the eigenvectors assoicated to the smallest eigenvalue.
 513                x = eig_vec_s[:,eig_val_s>1e-7] / np.sqrt(eig_val_s[eig_val_s>1e-7])
 514            xHx = x.T @ H @ x
 515            #Solve the canonical eigenvalue equation HC = CE
 516            eigvalues, eigvectors = scipy.linalg.eigh(xHx)
 517            eigvectors = np.dot(x, eigvectors)
 518
 519        idx = np.argmax(np.abs(eigvectors.real), axis=0)
 520        eigvectors[:,eigvectors[idx,np.arange(len(eigvalues))].real<0] *= -1
 521        return eigvalues, eigvectors # E, C
 522    
 523    def solve_cupy(self, H, S, orthogonalize=True):
 524        """
 525        Solve the generalized eigenvalue problem using CuPy (GPU).
 526
 527        Parameters
 528        ----------
 529        H : cp.ndarray
 530            Hamiltonian matrix (on GPU).
 531
 532        S : cp.ndarray
 533            Overlap matrix (on GPU).
 534
 535        orthogonalize : bool, optional
 536            If True, solve using orthogonalized basis.
 537
 538        Returns
 539        -------
 540        tuple of (cp.ndarray, cp.ndarray)
 541            Eigenvalues and eigenvectors (on GPU).
 542        """
 543        eig_val_s, eig_vec_s = cp.linalg.eigh(S)
 544        # Removing the eigenvectors assoicated to the smallest eigenvalue.
 545        x = eig_vec_s[:,eig_val_s>1e-7] / cp.sqrt(eig_val_s[eig_val_s>1e-7])
 546        xhx = x.T @ H @ x
 547        #Solve the canonical eigenvalue equation HC = SCE
 548        eigvalues, eigvectors = cp.linalg.eigh(xhx)
 549        eigvectors = cp.dot(x, eigvectors)
 550
 551        idx = cp.argmax(cp.abs(eigvectors.real), axis=0)
 552        eigvectors[:,eigvectors[idx,cp.arange(len(eigvalues))].real<0] *= -1
 553        return eigvalues, eigvectors # E, C
 554    
 555
 556    def getCoreH(self, mol=None, basis=None):
 557        """
 558        Compute the core Hamiltonian matrix (T + V).
 559
 560        Parameters
 561        ----------
 562        mol : Molecule, optional
 563            Molecule object.
 564
 565        basis : Basis, optional
 566            Basis set object.
 567
 568        Returns
 569        -------
 570        ndarray
 571            Core Hamiltonian matrix.
 572        """
 573        #Get the core Hamiltonian
 574        if mol is None:
 575            mol = self.mol
 576        if basis is None:
 577            basis = self.basis
 578        nao = basis.bfs_nao 
 579        H = np.empty((nao,nao))
 580        Vmat = Integrals.nuc_mat_symm(basis, mol)
 581        Tmat = Integrals.kin_mat_symm(basis)
 582        H = Vmat + Tmat
 583
 584        return H
 585
 586
 587    def guessCoreH(self, mol=None, basis=None, Hcore=None, S=None):
 588        """
 589        Generate a guess density matrix using the core Hamiltonian.
 590
 591        Parameters
 592        ----------
 593        mol : Molecule, optional
 594            Molecule object.
 595
 596        basis : Basis, optional
 597            Basis set.
 598
 599        Hcore : ndarray, optional
 600            Core Hamiltonian. If None, it will be computed.
 601
 602        S : ndarray, optional
 603            Overlap matrix. If None, it will be computed.
 604
 605        Returns
 606        -------
 607        ndarray
 608            Initial guess density matrix.
 609        """
 610        #Get a guess for the density matrix using the core Hamiltonian
 611        if mol is None:
 612            mol = self.mol
 613        if basis is None:
 614            basis = self.basis
 615        if Hcore is None:
 616            Hcore = self.getCoreH(mol, basis)
 617        if S is None:
 618            S = Integrals.overlap_mat_symm(basis)
 619
 620        eigvalues, eigvectors = scipy.linalg.eigh(Hcore, S)
 621        # print(eigvalues)
 622        idx = np.argmax(abs(eigvectors.real), axis=0)
 623        eigvectors[:,eigvectors[idx,np.arange(len(eigvalues))].real<0] *= -1
 624        mo_occ = self.getOcc(mol, eigvalues, eigvectors)
 625        # print(mo_occ)
 626        dmat = self.gen_dm(eigvectors, mo_occ)
 627
 628        return dmat
 629    
 630
 631    def DIIS(self,S,D,F):
 632        """
 633        Perform Direct Inversion in the Iterative Subspace (DIIS) to improve SCF convergence.
 634
 635        Adapted from
 636        ----------
 637        McMurchie-Davidson project:
 638        https://github.com/jjgoings/McMurchie-Davidson
 639        Licensed under the BSD-3-Clause license
 640
 641        Parameters
 642        ----------
 643        S : ndarray
 644            Overlap matrix.
 645
 646        D : ndarray
 647            Density matrix.
 648
 649        F : ndarray
 650            Fock matrix.
 651
 652        Returns
 653        -------
 654        ndarray
 655            DIIS-extrapolated Fock matrix.
 656        """
 657        FDS =   dot([F,D,S])
 658        # SDF =   np.conjugate(FDS).T 
 659        errVec = FDS - np.conjugate(FDS).T 
 660        self.KSmats.append(F)
 661        self.errVecs.append(errVec) 
 662        nKS = len(self.KSmats)
 663        if nKS > self.diisSpace:
 664            self.KSmats.pop(0) 
 665            self.errVecs.pop(0)
 666            nKS = nKS - 1
 667        B = np.zeros((nKS + 1,nKS + 1)) 
 668        B[-1,:] = B[:,-1] = -1.0
 669        B[-1,-1] = 0.0
 670        # B is symmetric
 671        for i in range(nKS):
 672            for j in range(i+1):
 673                B[i,j] = B[j,i] = \
 674                    np.real(np.trace(np.dot(np.conjugate(self.errVecs[i]).T, self.errVecs[j])))
 675        # for i in range(nKS):
 676        #     for j in range(i+1):
 677        #         print(self.errVecs[i].shape)
 678        #         B[i,j] = np.real(np.dot(np.conjugate(self.errVecs[i]).T, self.errVecs[j]))
 679        #         B[j,i] = B[i,j]
 680                                                    
 681        residual = np.zeros((nKS + 1, 1))
 682        residual[-1] = -1.0
 683        weights = scipy.linalg.solve(B,residual)
 684
 685        # weights is 1 x numFock + 1, but first numFock values
 686        # should sum to one if we are doing DIIS correctly
 687        assert np.isclose(sum(weights[:-1]),1.0)
 688
 689        F = np.zeros(F.shape)
 690        for i, KS in enumerate(self.KSmats):
 691            weight = weights[i]
 692            F += numexpr.evaluate('(weight * KS)')
 693
 694        return F 
 695    
 696    def DIIS_cupy(self,S,D,F):
 697        """
 698        Perform DIIS on GPU using CuPy to accelerate SCF convergence.
 699
 700        Adapted from
 701        ----------
 702        McMurchie-Davidson project:
 703        https://github.com/jjgoings/McMurchie-Davidson
 704        Licensed under the BSD-3-Clause license
 705
 706        Parameters
 707        ----------
 708        S : cp.ndarray
 709            Overlap matrix (on GPU).
 710
 711        D : cp.ndarray
 712            Density matrix (on GPU).
 713
 714        F : cp.ndarray
 715            Fock matrix (on GPU).
 716
 717        Returns
 718        -------
 719        cp.ndarray
 720            DIIS-extrapolated Fock matrix (on GPU).
 721        """
 722        FDS =   F @ D @ S
 723        errVec = FDS - cp.conjugate(FDS).T 
 724        self.KSmats.append(F)
 725        self.errVecs.append(errVec) 
 726        nKS = len(self.KSmats)
 727        if nKS > self.diisSpace:
 728            self.KSmats.pop(0) 
 729            self.errVecs.pop(0)
 730            nKS = nKS - 1
 731        B = cp.zeros((nKS + 1,nKS + 1)) 
 732        B[-1,:] = B[:,-1] = -1.0
 733        B[-1,-1] = 0.0
 734        # B is symmetric
 735        for i in range(nKS):
 736            for j in range(i+1):
 737                B[i,j] = B[j,i] = \
 738                    cp.real(cp.trace(cp.dot(cp.conjugate(self.errVecs[i]).T, self.errVecs[j])))
 739                                                    
 740        residual = cp.zeros((nKS + 1, 1))
 741        residual[-1] = -1.0
 742        weights = cp.linalg.solve(B,residual)
 743
 744        # weights is 1 x numFock + 1, but first numFock values
 745        # should sum to one if we are doing DIIS correctly
 746        assert cp.isclose(sum(weights[:-1]),1.0)
 747
 748        F = cp.zeros(F.shape)
 749        for i, KS in enumerate(self.KSmats):
 750            weight = weights[i]
 751            F += weight * KS
 752
 753        return F 
 754
 755    # @profile
 756    def scf(self):
 757        """
 758        Perform Self-Consistent Field (SCF) calculation for Density Functional Theory (DFT).
 759        
 760        This method implements a complete DFT SCF procedure including:
 761        - One-electron integral calculation (overlap, kinetic, nuclear attraction)
 762        - Two-electron integral calculation (4-center ERIs or density fitting)
 763        - Grid generation and pruning for exchange-correlation evaluation
 764        - Iterative SCF cycles with DIIS convergence acceleration
 765        - Exchange-correlation energy and potential evaluation using LibXC
 766        - GPU acceleration support for performance-critical operations
 767        
 768        The implementation supports multiple algorithmic variants:
 769        - Density fitting (DF)
 770        - Schwarz screening for integral sparsity
 771        - Multiple XC evaluation algorithms (CPU/GPU optimized)
 772        - Dynamic precision switching for GPU calculations
 773        
 774        SCF Procedure:
 775        1. Initialize one-electron integrals (S, T, V_nuc)
 776        2. Calculate/prepare two-electron integrals with optional screening
 777        3. Generate and prune integration grids for XC evaluation
 778        4. Iterative SCF loop:
 779        - Build Coulomb matrix J from density matrix
 780        - Evaluate exchange-correlation energy/potential on grids
 781        - Form Kohn-Sham matrix: H_KS = H_core + J + V_xc
 782        - Apply DIIS convergence acceleration
 783        - Diagonalize KS matrix to get new orbitals
 784        - Generate new density matrix from occupied orbitals
 785        - Check energy convergence
 786        5. Return converged total energy and density matrix
 787        
 788        Computational Features:
 789        - Multi-threading support via Numba and configurable core count
 790        - GPU acceleration using CuPy for grid-based operations
 791        - Memory-efficient batched evaluation of XC terms
 792        - Multiple density fitting algorithms (DF_algo 1-10)
 793        - Basis function screening for XC evaluation efficiency
 794        - Optional Cholesky decomposition for 2-center integrals
 795        
 796        Returns:
 797        --------
 798        tuple[float, numpy.ndarray]
 799            Etot : float
 800                Converged total electronic energy in atomic units
 801            dmat : numpy.ndarray, shape (nbf, nbf)
 802                Converged density matrix in atomic orbital basis
 803                
 804        Raises:
 805        -------
 806        ConvergenceError
 807            If SCF fails to converge within max_itr iterations
 808            
 809        Notes:
 810        ------
 811        - Uses class attributes for all computational parameters (basis, xc, conv_crit, etc.)
 812        - Extensive timing and profiling information printed during execution
 813        - Memory usage information displayed for large arrays
 814        - GPU memory automatically freed after completion
 815        - Supports both Cartesian (CAO) and Spherical (SAO) atomic orbital bases
 816        
 817        The function performs comprehensive error checking and provides detailed
 818        timing breakdowns for performance analysis. GPU acceleration is automatically
 819        enabled when CuPy is available and use_gpu=True.
 820        
 821        Example Energy Components:
 822        - Electron-nuclear attraction energy
 823        - Nuclear repulsion energy  
 824        - Kinetic energy
 825        - Coulomb (electron-electron repulsion) energy
 826        - Exchange-correlation energy
 827        """
 828        #### Timings
 829        duration1e = 0
 830        durationDIIS = 0
 831        durationAO_values = 0
 832        durationCoulomb = 0
 833        durationgrids = 0
 834        durationItr = 0
 835        durationxc = 0
 836        durationXCpreprocessing = 0
 837        durationDF = 0
 838        durationKS = 0
 839        durationSCF = 0
 840        durationgrids_prune_rho = 0
 841        durationSchwarz = 0
 842        duration2c2e = 0
 843        durationDF_coeff = 0
 844        durationDF_gamma = 0
 845        durationDF_Jtri = 0
 846        durationDF_cholesky = 0
 847        startSCF = timer()    
 848
 849        mol = self.mol
 850        basis = self.basis
 851        dmat = self.dmat
 852        xc = self.xc
 853        conv_crit = self.conv_crit
 854        max_itr = self.max_itr
 855        ncores = self.ncores
 856        grids = self.grids
 857        gridsLevel = self.gridsLevel
 858        isDF = self.isDF
 859        auxbasis = self.auxbasis
 860        rys = self.rys
 861        DF_algo = self.DF_algo
 862        blocksize = self.blocksize
 863        XC_algo = self.XC_algo
 864        debug = self.debug
 865        sortGrids = self.sortGrids
 866        save_ao_values = self.save_ao_values
 867        xc_bf_screen = self.xc_bf_screen
 868        threshold_schwarz = self.threshold_schwarz
 869        strict_schwarz = self.strict_schwarz
 870        cholesky = self.cholesky
 871        orthogonalize = self.orthogonalize
 872
 873        print_pyfock_logo()
 874        print('\n\nNumber of atoms:', mol.natoms)
 875        print('\n\nNumber of basis functions (atomic orbitals):', basis.bfs_nao)
 876        print('\n\nNumber of auxiliary basis functions:', auxbasis.bfs_nao)
 877        print('\n\n================================================================================\n\n')
 878
 879        print_sys_info()
 880
 881        #### Set number of cores
 882        numba.set_num_threads(ncores)
 883        os.environ['RAYON_NUM_THREADS'] = str(ncores)
 884        
 885        print('Running DFT using '+str(numba.get_num_threads())+' threads for Numba.\n\n', flush=True)
 886        # if basis is None:
 887        #     basis = self.basis
 888        # if mol is None:
 889        #     mol = self.mol
 890        # if xc is None:
 891        #     xc = self.xc
 892        # if gridsLevel is None:
 893        #     gridsLevel = self.gridsLevel
 894        # if auxbasis is None:
 895        #     auxbasis = Basis(mol, {'all':Basis.load(mol=mol, basis_name='def2-universal-jfit')})
 896        if grids is None:
 897            sortGrids = True
 898        if xc_bf_screen==False:
 899            if save_ao_values==True:
 900                print('Warning! AO screening is set to False, but AO values are requested to be saved. \
 901                      AO values can only be saved when XC_BF_SCREEN=TRUE. AO values will not be saved.', flush=True)
 902                save_ao_values = False
 903        if CUPY_AVAILABLE:
 904            if self.use_gpu:
 905                print('GPU acceleration is enabled. Currently this only accelerates AO values and XC term evaluation.', flush=True)
 906                print('GPU(s) information:')
 907                # print(cp.cuda.Device.mem_info())
 908                print(cuda.detect())
 909                print('Max threads per block supported by the GPU: ', cuda.get_current_device().MAX_THREADS_PER_BLOCK, flush=True)
 910                print('The user has specified to use '+str(self.n_gpus)+' GPU(s).')
 911            
 912                # For CUDA computations
 913                threads_per_block = (self.threads_x, self.threads_y)
 914                print('Threads per block configuration for the XC term: ', threads_per_block, flush=True)
 915                print('Threads per block configuration for the all other calculations: ', (32, 32), flush=True)
 916                if self.dynamic_precision:
 917                    print('\n\nWill use dynamic precision. ')
 918                    print('This means that the XC term will be evaluated in single precision until the ')
 919                    print('relative energy difference b/w successive iterations is less than 5.0E-7.')
 920                    precision_XC = cp.float32
 921                else:
 922                    precision_XC = cp.float64
 923
 924                if XC_algo is None:
 925                    XC_algo = 3
 926                if blocksize is None:
 927                    blocksize = 20480
 928                streams = []
 929                nb_streams = []
 930                for i in range(self.n_gpus):
 931                    cp.cuda.Device(i).use()
 932                    cp_stream = cp.cuda.Stream(non_blocking = True)
 933                    nb_stream = cuda.external_stream(cp_stream.ptr)
 934                    streams.append(cp_stream)
 935                    nb_streams.append(nb_stream)
 936                # Switch back to main GPU
 937                cp.cuda.Device(0).use()
 938                streams[0].use()
 939                # # Set some basis function data as cupy arrays to avoid redoing it during XC term evaluation at every SCF iteration
 940                # bfs_coords = cp.asarray([basis.bfs_coords], dtype=precision_XC)
 941                # bfs_contr_prim_norms = cp.asarray([basis.bfs_contr_prim_norms], dtype=precision_XC)
 942                # bfs_lmn = cp.asarray([basis.bfs_lmn])
 943                # bfs_nprim = cp.asarray([basis.bfs_nprim])
 944                # #The remaining properties like bfs_coeffs are a list of lists of unequal sizes.
 945                # #Numba won't be able to work with these efficiently.
 946                # #So, we convert them to a numpy 2d array by applying a trick,
 947                # #that the second dimension is that of the largest list. So that
 948                # #it can accomadate all the lists.
 949                # maxnprim = max(basis.bfs_nprim)
 950                # bfs_coeffs = cp.zeros([basis.bfs_nao, maxnprim], dtype=precision_XC)
 951                # bfs_expnts = cp.zeros([basis.bfs_nao, maxnprim], dtype=precision_XC)
 952                # bfs_prim_norms = cp.zeros([basis.bfs_nao, maxnprim], dtype=precision_XC)
 953                # bfs_radius_cutoff = cp.zeros([basis.bfs_nao], dtype=precision_XC)
 954                # for i in range(basis.bfs_nao):
 955                #     for j in range(basis.bfs_nprim[i]):
 956                #         bfs_coeffs[i,j] = basis.bfs_coeffs[i][j]
 957                #         bfs_expnts[i,j] = basis.bfs_expnts[i][j]
 958                #         bfs_prim_norms[i,j] = basis.bfs_prim_norms[i][j]
 959                #         bfs_radius_cutoff[i] = basis.bfs_radius_cutoff[i]
 960                # # Now bf/ao values can be evaluated by calling the following
 961                # # bf_values = Integrals.bf_val_helpers.eval_bfs(bfs_coords[0], bfs_contr_prim_norms[0], bfs_nprim[0], bfs_lmn[0], bfs_coeffs, bfs_prim_norms, bfs_expnts, bfs_radius_cutoff, coord)
 962                # bfs_data_as_np_arrays = [bfs_coords[0], bfs_contr_prim_norms[0], bfs_nprim[0], bfs_lmn[0], bfs_coeffs, bfs_prim_norms, bfs_expnts, bfs_radius_cutoff]
 963

 971                    XC_algo = 2

 973                    blocksize = 5000

 975            isSchwarz = True

 997        # DF_algo = 2 # Sligthly better (2x memory efficient) algorithm than above (requires 1x mem of 3c2e integrals and a large prefactor)

1001        # DF_algo = 6 # Much cheaper than 4 and 5 in terms of memory requirements because the indices of significant (ij|P) are efficiently calculated without duplicates/temporary arrays.

1004        # DF_algo = 8 # Similar to 6, except that here the significant indices are not stored resulting in 50% memory savings. The drawback is that it only works in serial which is useful for Google colab or Kaggle perhaps.
1005        # DF_algo = 9 #

1008            start1e = timer()
1009            print('\nCalculating one electron integrals...\n\n', flush=True)

1028        else:
1029            start1e = timer()
1030            print('\nCalculating overlap and kinetic integrals...\n\n', flush=True)
1031            # One electron integrals
1032            if not self.use_gpu:
1033                S = Integrals.overlap_mat_symm(basis)
1034                T = Integrals.kin_mat_symm(basis)
1035                # Core hamiltonian

1057
1058

1064                # Later the dmat will be converted back to SAO after J and XC term evaluations
1065        if not isDF: # 4c2e ERI case
1066

1070                if rys:

1072                else:

1076            else:
1077                print('\n\nPerforming Schwarz screening...')
1078                # threshold_schwarz = 1e-09
1079                print('Threshold ', threshold_schwarz)
1080                startSchwarz = timer()
1081                nints4c2e_sym8 = int(basis.bfs_nao**4/8)
1082                nints4c2e = int(basis.bfs_nao**4)
1083                duration_4c2e_diag = 0.0
1084                start_4c2e_diag = timer()

1090                duration_square_roots = 0.0
1091                start_square_roots = timer()
1092                sqrt_ints4c2e_diag = np.sqrt(np.abs(ints4c2e_diag))

1094                print('Time taken to evaluate the square roots needed: ', duration_square_roots)

1096                duration_indices_calc = 0.0
1097                duration_concatenation = 0.0
1098                start_indices_calc = timer()
1099                # indices_temp = []
1100                ijkl = [0, 0, 0, 0]
1101                if chunksize<nints4c2e_sym8:
1102                    nchunks = nints4c2e_sym8//chunksize + 1
1103                else:
1104                    nchunks=1
1105                indicesA = None
1106                for ichunk in range(nchunks):
1107                    indices_temp = Integrals.schwarz_helpers.calc_indices_4c2e_schwarz(sqrt_ints4c2e_diag, min(chunksize, nints4c2e_sym8), basis.bfs_nao, ijkl[0], ijkl[1], ijkl[2], ijkl[3], threshold_schwarz)
1108                    
1109                    ijkl = indices_temp[4]
1110                    count = indices_temp[5]
1111                    # start_concatenation = timer()
1112                    if indicesA is not None and count>0:
1113                        indicesA = np.concatenate([indicesA, indices_temp[0][0:count]])
1114                        indicesB = np.concatenate([indicesB, indices_temp[1][0:count]])
1115                        indicesC = np.concatenate([indicesC, indices_temp[2][0:count]])
1116                        indicesD = np.concatenate([indicesD, indices_temp[3][0:count]])
1117                    else:
1118                        
1119                        indicesA = indices_temp[0][0:count]
1120                        indicesB = indices_temp[1][0:count]
1121                        indicesC = indices_temp[2][0:count]
1122                        indicesD = indices_temp[3][0:count]
1123                    # duration_concatenation += timer() - start_concatenation
1124                    # Break out of the for loop if the nol. of significant triplets found is less than the chunksize 
1125                    # This is because, it means that there are no more significant triplets to be found from all possible configurations. 
1126                    if count<chunksize: 
1127                        break
1128                
1129                duration_indices_calc += timer() - start_indices_calc
1130                print('Time for significant indices evaluation: ', duration_indices_calc)
1131                # print('Time for array concatenation: ', duration_concatenation)
1132
1133                # Get rid of temp variables
1134                indices_temp=0
1135                ijk = 0
1136                
1137                print('Size of permanent array storing the significant indices of 4c2e ERI in GB ', indicesA.nbytes/1e9+indicesB.nbytes/1e9+indicesC.nbytes/1e9+indicesD.nbytes/1e9, flush=True)
1138
1139                nsignificant = len(indicesA)
1140                print('No. of elements in the standard four-centered two electron ERI tensor: ', nints4c2e, flush=True)
1141                print('No. of elements after factoring in the 8-fold symmetry in the four-centered two electron ERI tensor: ', nints4c2e_sym8, flush=True)
1142                print('No. of significant quadruplets based on Schwarz inequality and 8-fold symmetry: ' + str(nsignificant) + ' or '+str(np.round(nsignificant/nints4c2e*100,1)) + '% of original', flush=True)
1143                print('Schwarz screening done!')
1144                durationSchwarz = timer() - startSchwarz
1145                print('Total time taken for Schwarz screening '+str(durationSchwarz)+' seconds.\n', flush=True)
1146
1147                ints4c2e = Integrals.schwarz_helpers.rys_4c2e_tri_schwarz_sparse(basis, auxbasis, indicesA, indicesB, indicesC, indicesD)
1148

1387            # I use a trick to calculate the DFT energy in SAO basis. 
1388            # The trick is to get rid of the extra information in the CAO basis matrices.
1389            # The following does just that. 
1390            # Going from CAO --> SAO we lose the extra information then we go back to from SAO --> CAO
1391            # This way all the integrals (potential matrices and density matrices) can still be calculated
1392            # in the CAO basis. In fact even the KS matrix is diagonalized in the CAO basis with the extra information 
1393            # removed by forward and backward transformation: CAO --> SAO followed by SAO --> CAO.
1394            # This also helps in reducing the number of transformations needed for calculation of various energy contributions.
1395            #########
1396            # Convert the overlap matrix from CAO to SAO basis
1397            S = np.dot(c2sph_mat, np.dot(S, c2sph_mat.T)) # CAO --> SAO

1403                # Removing the eigenvectors assoicated to the smallest eigenvalue.
1404                x = eig_vec_s[:,eig_val_s>1e-7] / np.sqrt(eig_val_s[eig_val_s>1e-7])

1554                with threadpool_limits(limits=ncores, user_api='blas'):
1555                    # print('KS eigh', controller.info())
1556                    eigvalues, eigvectors = self.solve(KS, S, orthogonalize=orthogonalize, x=x)
1557                mo_occ = self.getOcc(mol, eigvalues, eigvectors)
1558                dmat = self.gen_dm(eigvectors, mo_occ)
1559            durationKS = durationKS + timer() - startKS
1560
1561            # Check when to switch to double precision for XC
1562            if self.use_gpu:
1563                if precision_XC is cp.float32:
1564                    if abs(Etot_new-Etot)/abs(Etot_new)<5e-7:
1565                        precision_XC = cp.float64
1566                        print('\nSwitching to double precision for XC evaluation after '+str(itr) +' iterations!', flush=True)
1567                        
1568
1569
1570            durationItr = timer() - startIter
1571            print('\n\nTime taken for the previous iteration: '+str(durationItr)+'\n\n', flush=True)
1572
1573            # Check convergence criteria
1574            if abs(Etot_new-Etot)<conv_crit:
1575                scf_converged = True
1576                print('\nSCF Converged after '+str(itr) +' iterations!', flush=True)
1577                Etot = Etot_new
1578                print('\n-------------------------------------', flush=True)
1579                print('Total Energy = ', Etot, flush=True)
1580                print('-------------------------------------\n\n', flush=True)
1581                break
1582
1583            Etot = Etot_new
1584            itr = itr + 1
1585            
1586
1587        if itr>=max_itr and not scf_converged:
1588            print('\nSCF NOT Converged after '+str(itr-1) +' iterations!', flush=True)
1589
1590
1591        durationSCF = timer() - startSCF
1592        # print(dmat)
1593        print('\nTime taken : '+str(durationSCF) +' seconds.', flush=True)
1594        print('\n\n', flush=True)
1595        print('-------------------------------------', flush=True)
1596        print('Profiling', flush=True)
1597        print('-------------------------------------', flush=True)
1598        print('Preprocessing                          ', durationXCpreprocessing + durationAO_values + durationgrids_prune_rho + durationSchwarz)
1599        if isDF:
1600            print('Density Fitting                        ', durationDF, flush=True)
1601            if DF_algo==6 or DF_algo==10:
1602                print('    DF (gamma)                         ', durationDF_gamma, flush=True)
1603                print('    DF (coeff)                         ', durationDF_coeff, flush=True)
1604                print('    DF (Jtri)                          ', durationDF_Jtri, flush=True)
1605                if cholesky:
1606                    print('    DF (Cholesky)                      ', durationDF_cholesky, flush=True)
1607        print('DIIS                                   ', durationDIIS, flush=True)
1608        print('KS matrix diagonalization              ', durationKS, flush=True)
1609        print('One electron Integrals (S, T, Vnuc)    ', duration1e, flush=True)
1610        if isDF:
1611            print('Coulomb Integrals (2c2e + 3c2e)        ', durationCoulomb-durationSchwarz-durationDF_cholesky, flush=True)
1612        if not isDF:
1613            print('Coulomb Integrals (4c2e)               ', durationCoulomb-durationSchwarz, flush=True)
1614        print('Grids construction                     ', durationgrids, flush=True)
1615        print('Exchange-Correlation Term              ', durationxc, flush=True)
1616        totalTime = durationXCpreprocessing + durationAO_values + duration1e + durationCoulomb - durationDF_cholesky + \
1617            durationgrids + durationxc + durationDF + durationKS + durationDIIS + durationgrids_prune_rho 
1618        print('Misc.                                  ', durationSCF - totalTime, flush=True)
1619        print('Complete SCF                           ', durationSCF, flush=True)
1620
1621        if self.use_gpu:
1622            # Free memory of all GPUs
1623            for igpu in range(self.n_gpus):
1624                cp.cuda.Device(igpu).use()
1625                cp._default_memory_pool.free_all_blocks()
1626
1627            # Switch back to main GPU
1628            cp.cuda.Device(0).use()
1629        return Etot, dmat

A class for performing Density Functional Theory (DFT) calculations with optional support for density fitting (DF), GPU acceleration, and LibXC.

Parameters

mol : Molecule Molecular object on which the DFT calculation is to be performed.

basis : Basis Orbital basis set used for the SCF calculation.

auxbasis : Basis, optional Auxiliary basis set for density fitting (DF). If None, a default will be assigned.

conv_crit : float, optional Convergence criterion for the SCF cycle in Hartrees (default is 1e-7).

dmat_guess_method : str, optional Method for the initial density matrix guess (e.g., 'core', 'huckel').

xc : list or str, optional Exchange-correlation functional specification. If None, defaults to LDA ([1, 7]).

grids : object, optional Precomputed numerical integration grids. If None, they will be generated automatically.

gridsLevel : int, optional Level of numerical integration grid refinement (default is 3).

blocksize : int, optional Block size for XC grid evaluations. Defaults depend on whether GPU is used.

save_ao_values : bool, optional If True, saves AO values to reuse during XC evaluation. Increases speed but uses more memory.

use_gpu : bool, optional Whether to use GPU acceleration.

ncores : int, optional Number of CPU cores to use (default is 2).

Attributes

dmat : ndarray Initial guess for the density matrix, will be computed during setup.

KSmats : list List of Kohn–Sham matrices used in DIIS extrapolation.

errVecs : list List of error vectors for DIIS.

max_itr : int Maximum number of SCF iterations (default is 50).

isDF : bool Whether to use density fitting for Coulomb integrals.

rys : bool Whether to use Rys quadrature for evaluating electron repulsion integrals.

DF_algo : int Algorithm selector for DF (reserved for developer use).

XC_algo : int Algorithm selector for XC evaluation (2 for CPU, 3 for GPU).

sortGrids : bool Whether to sort DFT integration grids (not recommended).

xc_bf_screen : bool Enable basis function screening for XC term evaluation.

threshold_schwarz : float Threshold for Schwarz screening (default is 1e-9).

strict_schwarz : bool If True, applies stricter Schwarz screening.

cholesky : bool If True, uses Cholesky decomposition for DF.

orthogonalize : bool If True, orthogonalizes AO basis functions.

sao : bool If True, uses SAO basis instead of CAO basis.

keep_ao_in_gpu : bool Whether to retain AO values in GPU memory during SCF (if save_ao_values is True).

use_libxc : bool Whether to use LibXC for XC functional evaluation (recommended off for GPU).

n_streams : int Number of CUDA streams to use (if applicable).

n_gpus : int Number of GPUs to use.

free_gpu_mem : bool Whether to forcibly free GPU memory after use.

max_threads_per_block : int Maximum threads per CUDA block supported by the device.

threads_x : int CUDA thread configuration (X dimension).

threads_y : int CUDA thread configuration (Y dimension).

dynamic_precision : bool Whether to use precision switching during XC evaluation for performance gains.

keep_ints3c2e_in_gpu : bool Whether to keep 3-center 2-electron integrals in GPU memory to avoid transfers.

debug : bool If True, prints debugging output during DFT calculations.

Notes

  • This class supports SCF DFT calculations with density fitting (DF).
  • GPU support is optional and provides significant speed-up for large systems.
  • The class is tightly integrated with PyFock and LibXC libraries.

Examples

>>> mol = Molecule(...)
>>> basis = Basis(mol, ...)
>>> dft = DFT(mol, basis, xc='PBE', use_gpu=True)
>>> dft.run_scf()

def nuclear_rep_energy(self, mol=None): 
356    def nuclear_rep_energy(self, mol=None):
357        """
358        Compute the nuclear-nuclear repulsion energy.
359
360        Parameters
361        ----------
362        mol : Molecule, optional
363            Molecule object containing nuclear coordinates and charges. 
364            If None, uses `self.mol`.
365
366        Returns
367        -------
368        float
369            The nuclear repulsion energy in Hartrees.
370        """
371        # Nuclear-nuclear energy
372        if mol is None: 
373            mol = self.mol
374    
375        e = 0
376        for i in range(mol.natoms):
377            for j in range(i, mol.natoms):
378                if (i!=j):
379                    dist = mol.coordsBohrs[i]-mol.coordsBohrs[j]
380                    e = e + mol.Zcharges[i]*mol.Zcharges[j]/np.sqrt(np.sum(dist**2))
381
382        return e

Returns

float The nuclear repulsion energy in Hartrees.

def gen_dm(self, mo_coeff, mo_occ): 
385    def gen_dm(self, mo_coeff, mo_occ):
386        """
387        Generate the density matrix from molecular orbital coefficients and occupations.
388
389        Parameters
390        ----------
391        mo_coeff : ndarray
392            Molecular orbital coefficient matrix.
393
394        mo_occ : ndarray
395            Array of MO occupation numbers.
396
397        Returns
398        -------
399        ndarray
400            Density matrix (RHF/RKS type).
401        """
402        mocc = mo_coeff[:,mo_occ>0]
403   
404        return np.dot(mocc*mo_occ[mo_occ>0], mocc.conj().T)

def getOcc(self, mol=None, energy_mo=None, coeff_mo=None): 
406    def getOcc(self, mol=None, energy_mo=None, coeff_mo=None):
407        """
408        Assign occupation numbers to molecular orbitals based on their energies.
409
410        Parameters
411        ----------
412        mol : Molecule
413            Molecule object to extract the number of electrons.
414
415        energy_mo : ndarray
416            Array of MO energies.
417
418        coeff_mo : ndarray
419            Array of MO coefficients (not used but kept for compatibility).
420
421        Returns
422        -------
423        ndarray
424            Array of MO occupations (0 or 2 for RHF).
425        """
426        e_idx = np.argsort(energy_mo)
427        e_sort = energy_mo[e_idx]
428        nmo = energy_mo.size
429        occ_mo = np.zeros(nmo)
430        nocc = mol.nelectrons // 2
431        occ_mo[e_idx[:nocc]] = 2
432        return occ_mo

coeff_mo : ndarray Array of MO coefficients (not used but kept for compatibility).

Returns

def solve(self, H, S, orthogonalize=False, x=None): 
482    def solve(self, H, S, orthogonalize=False, x=None):
483        """
484        Solve the generalized or canonical eigenvalue equation.
485
486        Parameters
487        ----------
488        H : ndarray
489            Hamiltonian matrix.
490
491        S : ndarray
492            Overlap matrix.
493
494        orthogonalize : bool, optional
495            If True, solve using orthogonalized basis.
496
497        x : ndarray, optional
498            Transformation matrix (if already computed).
499
500        Returns
501        -------
502        tuple of (ndarray, ndarray)
503            Eigenvalues and eigenvectors of the system.
504        """
505        if not orthogonalize:
506            #Solve the generalized eigenvalue equation HC = SCE
507            eigvalues, eigvectors = scipy.linalg.eigh(H, S)
508            
509        else:
510            if x is None:
511                eig_val_s, eig_vec_s = scipy.linalg.eigh(S)
512                # Removing the eigenvectors assoicated to the smallest eigenvalue.
513                x = eig_vec_s[:,eig_val_s>1e-7] / np.sqrt(eig_val_s[eig_val_s>1e-7])
514            xHx = x.T @ H @ x
515            #Solve the canonical eigenvalue equation HC = CE
516            eigvalues, eigvectors = scipy.linalg.eigh(xHx)
517            eigvectors = np.dot(x, eigvectors)
518
519        idx = np.argmax(np.abs(eigvectors.real), axis=0)
520        eigvectors[:,eigvectors[idx,np.arange(len(eigvalues))].real<0] *= -1
521        return eigvalues, eigvectors # E, C

Solve the generalized or canonical eigenvalue equation.

Parameters

H : ndarray Hamiltonian matrix.

S : ndarray Overlap matrix.

orthogonalize : bool, optional If True, solve using orthogonalized basis.

x : ndarray, optional Transformation matrix (if already computed).

Returns

tuple of (ndarray, ndarray) Eigenvalues and eigenvectors of the system.

def solve_cupy(self, H, S, orthogonalize=True): 
523    def solve_cupy(self, H, S, orthogonalize=True):
524        """
525        Solve the generalized eigenvalue problem using CuPy (GPU).
526
527        Parameters
528        ----------
529        H : cp.ndarray
530            Hamiltonian matrix (on GPU).
531
532        S : cp.ndarray
533            Overlap matrix (on GPU).
534
535        orthogonalize : bool, optional
536            If True, solve using orthogonalized basis.
537
538        Returns
539        -------
540        tuple of (cp.ndarray, cp.ndarray)
541            Eigenvalues and eigenvectors (on GPU).
542        """
543        eig_val_s, eig_vec_s = cp.linalg.eigh(S)
544        # Removing the eigenvectors assoicated to the smallest eigenvalue.
545        x = eig_vec_s[:,eig_val_s>1e-7] / cp.sqrt(eig_val_s[eig_val_s>1e-7])
546        xhx = x.T @ H @ x
547        #Solve the canonical eigenvalue equation HC = SCE
548        eigvalues, eigvectors = cp.linalg.eigh(xhx)
549        eigvectors = cp.dot(x, eigvectors)
550
551        idx = cp.argmax(cp.abs(eigvectors.real), axis=0)
552        eigvectors[:,eigvectors[idx,cp.arange(len(eigvalues))].real<0] *= -1
553        return eigvalues, eigvectors # E, C

Solve the generalized eigenvalue problem using CuPy (GPU).

Parameters

H : cp.ndarray Hamiltonian matrix (on GPU).

S : cp.ndarray Overlap matrix (on GPU).

orthogonalize : bool, optional If True, solve using orthogonalized basis.

Returns

tuple of (cp.ndarray, cp.ndarray) Eigenvalues and eigenvectors (on GPU).

def getCoreH(self, mol=None, basis=None): 
556    def getCoreH(self, mol=None, basis=None):
557        """
558        Compute the core Hamiltonian matrix (T + V).
559
560        Parameters
561        ----------
562        mol : Molecule, optional
563            Molecule object.
564
565        basis : Basis, optional
566            Basis set object.
567
568        Returns
569        -------
570        ndarray
571            Core Hamiltonian matrix.
572        """
573        #Get the core Hamiltonian
574        if mol is None:
575            mol = self.mol
576        if basis is None:
577            basis = self.basis
578        nao = basis.bfs_nao 
579        H = np.empty((nao,nao))
580        Vmat = Integrals.nuc_mat_symm(basis, mol)
581        Tmat = Integrals.kin_mat_symm(basis)
582        H = Vmat + Tmat
583
584        return H

Compute the core Hamiltonian matrix (T + V).

Parameters

mol : Molecule, optional Molecule object.

basis : Basis, optional Basis set object.

Returns

ndarray Core Hamiltonian matrix.

def guessCoreH(self, mol=None, basis=None, Hcore=None, S=None): 
587    def guessCoreH(self, mol=None, basis=None, Hcore=None, S=None):
588        """
589        Generate a guess density matrix using the core Hamiltonian.
590
591        Parameters
592        ----------
593        mol : Molecule, optional
594            Molecule object.
595
596        basis : Basis, optional
597            Basis set.
598
599        Hcore : ndarray, optional
600            Core Hamiltonian. If None, it will be computed.
601
602        S : ndarray, optional
603            Overlap matrix. If None, it will be computed.
604
605        Returns
606        -------
607        ndarray
608            Initial guess density matrix.
609        """
610        #Get a guess for the density matrix using the core Hamiltonian
611        if mol is None:
612            mol = self.mol
613        if basis is None:
614            basis = self.basis
615        if Hcore is None:
616            Hcore = self.getCoreH(mol, basis)
617        if S is None:
618            S = Integrals.overlap_mat_symm(basis)
619
620        eigvalues, eigvectors = scipy.linalg.eigh(Hcore, S)
621        # print(eigvalues)
622        idx = np.argmax(abs(eigvectors.real), axis=0)
623        eigvectors[:,eigvectors[idx,np.arange(len(eigvalues))].real<0] *= -1
624        mo_occ = self.getOcc(mol, eigvalues, eigvectors)
625        # print(mo_occ)
626        dmat = self.gen_dm(eigvectors, mo_occ)
627
628        return dmat

Generate a guess density matrix using the core Hamiltonian.

def DIIS(self, S, D, F): 
631    def DIIS(self,S,D,F):
632        """
633        Perform Direct Inversion in the Iterative Subspace (DIIS) to improve SCF convergence.
634
635        Adapted from
636        ----------
637        McMurchie-Davidson project:
638        https://github.com/jjgoings/McMurchie-Davidson
639        Licensed under the BSD-3-Clause license
640
641        Parameters
642        ----------
643        S : ndarray
644            Overlap matrix.
645
646        D : ndarray
647            Density matrix.
648
649        F : ndarray
650            Fock matrix.
651
652        Returns
653        -------
654        ndarray
655            DIIS-extrapolated Fock matrix.
656        """
657        FDS =   dot([F,D,S])
658        # SDF =   np.conjugate(FDS).T 
659        errVec = FDS - np.conjugate(FDS).T 
660        self.KSmats.append(F)
661        self.errVecs.append(errVec) 
662        nKS = len(self.KSmats)
663        if nKS > self.diisSpace:
664            self.KSmats.pop(0) 
665            self.errVecs.pop(0)
666            nKS = nKS - 1
667        B = np.zeros((nKS + 1,nKS + 1)) 
668        B[-1,:] = B[:,-1] = -1.0
669        B[-1,-1] = 0.0
670        # B is symmetric
671        for i in range(nKS):
672            for j in range(i+1):
673                B[i,j] = B[j,i] = \
674                    np.real(np.trace(np.dot(np.conjugate(self.errVecs[i]).T, self.errVecs[j])))
675        # for i in range(nKS):
676        #     for j in range(i+1):
677        #         print(self.errVecs[i].shape)
678        #         B[i,j] = np.real(np.dot(np.conjugate(self.errVecs[i]).T, self.errVecs[j]))
679        #         B[j,i] = B[i,j]
680                                                    
681        residual = np.zeros((nKS + 1, 1))
682        residual[-1] = -1.0
683        weights = scipy.linalg.solve(B,residual)
684
685        # weights is 1 x numFock + 1, but first numFock values
686        # should sum to one if we are doing DIIS correctly
687        assert np.isclose(sum(weights[:-1]),1.0)
688
689        F = np.zeros(F.shape)
690        for i, KS in enumerate(self.KSmats):
691            weight = weights[i]
692            F += numexpr.evaluate('(weight * KS)')
693
694        return F

Perform Direct Inversion in the Iterative Subspace (DIIS) to improve SCF convergence.

Adapted from

McMurchie-Davidson project: https://github.com/jjgoings/McMurchie-Davidson Licensed under the BSD-3-Clause license

Parameters

S : ndarray Overlap matrix.

D : ndarray Density matrix.

F : ndarray Fock matrix.

Returns

ndarray DIIS-extrapolated Fock matrix.

def DIIS_cupy(self, S, D, F): 
696    def DIIS_cupy(self,S,D,F):
697        """
698        Perform DIIS on GPU using CuPy to accelerate SCF convergence.
699
700        Adapted from
701        ----------
702        McMurchie-Davidson project:
703        https://github.com/jjgoings/McMurchie-Davidson
704        Licensed under the BSD-3-Clause license
705
706        Parameters
707        ----------
708        S : cp.ndarray
709            Overlap matrix (on GPU).
710
711        D : cp.ndarray
712            Density matrix (on GPU).
713
714        F : cp.ndarray
715            Fock matrix (on GPU).
716
717        Returns
718        -------
719        cp.ndarray
720            DIIS-extrapolated Fock matrix (on GPU).
721        """
722        FDS =   F @ D @ S
723        errVec = FDS - cp.conjugate(FDS).T 
724        self.KSmats.append(F)
725        self.errVecs.append(errVec) 
726        nKS = len(self.KSmats)
727        if nKS > self.diisSpace:
728            self.KSmats.pop(0) 
729            self.errVecs.pop(0)
730            nKS = nKS - 1
731        B = cp.zeros((nKS + 1,nKS + 1)) 
732        B[-1,:] = B[:,-1] = -1.0
733        B[-1,-1] = 0.0
734        # B is symmetric
735        for i in range(nKS):
736            for j in range(i+1):
737                B[i,j] = B[j,i] = \
738                    cp.real(cp.trace(cp.dot(cp.conjugate(self.errVecs[i]).T, self.errVecs[j])))
739                                                    
740        residual = cp.zeros((nKS + 1, 1))
741        residual[-1] = -1.0
742        weights = cp.linalg.solve(B,residual)
743
744        # weights is 1 x numFock + 1, but first numFock values
745        # should sum to one if we are doing DIIS correctly
746        assert cp.isclose(sum(weights[:-1]),1.0)
747
748        F = cp.zeros(F.shape)
749        for i, KS in enumerate(self.KSmats):
750            weight = weights[i]
751            F += weight * KS
752
753        return F

def scf(self): 
 756    def scf(self):
 757        """
 758        Perform Self-Consistent Field (SCF) calculation for Density Functional Theory (DFT).
 759        
 760        This method implements a complete DFT SCF procedure including:
 761        - One-electron integral calculation (overlap, kinetic, nuclear attraction)
 762        - Two-electron integral calculation (4-center ERIs or density fitting)
 763        - Grid generation and pruning for exchange-correlation evaluation
 764        - Iterative SCF cycles with DIIS convergence acceleration
 765        - Exchange-correlation energy and potential evaluation using LibXC
 766        - GPU acceleration support for performance-critical operations
 767        
 768        The implementation supports multiple algorithmic variants:
 769        - Density fitting (DF)
 770        - Schwarz screening for integral sparsity
 771        - Multiple XC evaluation algorithms (CPU/GPU optimized)
 772        - Dynamic precision switching for GPU calculations
 773        
 774        SCF Procedure:
 775        1. Initialize one-electron integrals (S, T, V_nuc)
 776        2. Calculate/prepare two-electron integrals with optional screening
 777        3. Generate and prune integration grids for XC evaluation
 778        4. Iterative SCF loop:
 779        - Build Coulomb matrix J from density matrix
 780        - Evaluate exchange-correlation energy/potential on grids
 781        - Form Kohn-Sham matrix: H_KS = H_core + J + V_xc
 782        - Apply DIIS convergence acceleration
 783        - Diagonalize KS matrix to get new orbitals
 784        - Generate new density matrix from occupied orbitals
 785        - Check energy convergence
 786        5. Return converged total energy and density matrix
 787        
 788        Computational Features:
 789        - Multi-threading support via Numba and configurable core count
 790        - GPU acceleration using CuPy for grid-based operations
 791        - Memory-efficient batched evaluation of XC terms
 792        - Multiple density fitting algorithms (DF_algo 1-10)
 793        - Basis function screening for XC evaluation efficiency
 794        - Optional Cholesky decomposition for 2-center integrals
 795        
 796        Returns:
 797        --------
 798        tuple[float, numpy.ndarray]
 799            Etot : float
 800                Converged total electronic energy in atomic units
 801            dmat : numpy.ndarray, shape (nbf, nbf)
 802                Converged density matrix in atomic orbital basis
 803                
 804        Raises:
 805        -------
 806        ConvergenceError
 807            If SCF fails to converge within max_itr iterations
 808            
 809        Notes:
 810        ------
 811        - Uses class attributes for all computational parameters (basis, xc, conv_crit, etc.)
 812        - Extensive timing and profiling information printed during execution
 813        - Memory usage information displayed for large arrays
 814        - GPU memory automatically freed after completion
 815        - Supports both Cartesian (CAO) and Spherical (SAO) atomic orbital bases
 816        
 817        The function performs comprehensive error checking and provides detailed
 818        timing breakdowns for performance analysis. GPU acceleration is automatically
 819        enabled when CuPy is available and use_gpu=True.
 820        
 821        Example Energy Components:
 822        - Electron-nuclear attraction energy
 823        - Nuclear repulsion energy  
 824        - Kinetic energy
 825        - Coulomb (electron-electron repulsion) energy
 826        - Exchange-correlation energy
 827        """
 828        #### Timings
 829        duration1e = 0
 830        durationDIIS = 0
 831        durationAO_values = 0
 832        durationCoulomb = 0
 833        durationgrids = 0
 834        durationItr = 0
 835        durationxc = 0
 836        durationXCpreprocessing = 0
 837        durationDF = 0
 838        durationKS = 0
 839        durationSCF = 0
 840        durationgrids_prune_rho = 0
 841        durationSchwarz = 0
 842        duration2c2e = 0
 843        durationDF_coeff = 0
 844        durationDF_gamma = 0
 845        durationDF_Jtri = 0
 846        durationDF_cholesky = 0
 847        startSCF = timer()    
 848
 849        mol = self.mol
 850        basis = self.basis
 851        dmat = self.dmat
 852        xc = self.xc
 853        conv_crit = self.conv_crit
 854        max_itr = self.max_itr
 855        ncores = self.ncores
 856        grids = self.grids
 857        gridsLevel = self.gridsLevel
 858        isDF = self.isDF
 859        auxbasis = self.auxbasis
 860        rys = self.rys

1387            # I use a trick to calculate the DFT energy in SAO basis. 
1388            # The trick is to get rid of the extra information in the CAO basis matrices.
1389            # The following does just that. 
1390            # Going from CAO --> SAO we lose the extra information then we go back to from SAO --> CAO
1391            # This way all the integrals (potential matrices and density matrices) can still be calculated
1392            # in the CAO basis. In fact even the KS matrix is diagonalized in the CAO basis with the extra information 
1393            # removed by forward and backward transformation: CAO --> SAO followed by SAO --> CAO.
1394            # This also helps in reducing the number of transformations needed for calculation of various energy contributions.
1395            #########
1396            # Convert the overlap matrix from CAO to SAO basis
1397            S = np.dot(c2sph_mat, np.dot(S, c2sph_mat.T)) # CAO --> SAO
1398            # Convert back to SAO so that now we lose the extra information that the CAO basis had

1489            if self.use_gpu:
1490                Enuc = contract('ij,ji->', dmat_cp, V)
1491                Ekin = contract('ij,ji->', dmat_cp, T)
1492                Ecoul = contract('ij,ji->', dmat_cp, J)*0.5
1493            else:
1494                with threadpool_limits(limits=ncores, user_api='blas'):
1495                    # print('Energy contractions', controller.info())
1496                    Enuc = contract('ij,ji->', dmat, V)
1497                    Ekin = contract('ij,ji->', dmat, T)
1498                    Ecoul = contract('ij,ji->', dmat, J)*0.5
1499            if isDF and (DF_algo==6 or DF_algo==10):
1500                Ecoul = Ecoul*2 - 0.5*Ecoul_temp # This is the correct formula for Coulomb energy with DF
1501
1502            Etot_new = Exc + Enuc + Ekin + Enn + Ecoul
1503
1504            print('\n\n\n------Iteration '+str(itr)+'--------\n\n', flush=True)
1505            print('Energies')
1506            print('Electron-Nuclear Energy      ', Enuc, flush=True)
1507            print('Nuclear repulsion Energy     ', Enn, flush=True)
1508            print('Kinetic Energy               ', Ekin, flush=True)
1509            print('Coulomb Energy               ', Ecoul, flush=True)
1510            print('Exchange-Correlation Energy  ', Exc, flush=True)
1511            print('-------------------------')
1512            print('Total Energy ',Etot_new, flush=True)
1513            print('-------------------------\n\n\n', flush=True)
1514
1515            print('Energy difference : ',abs(Etot_new-Etot), flush=True)
1516
1517            
1518
1519
1520            KS = H + J + Vxc 
1521            if self.sao:
1522                # The following gets rid of the extra information in the CAO basis KS matrix by going to SAO and then back to CAO.
1523                # This way even though the matrix dimensions would be that of CAO but the information would be the same as SAO
1524                # leading to the same energy as SAO basis PySCF or TURBOMOLE calculations
1525                KS = np.dot(c2sph_mat, np.dot(KS, c2sph_mat.T)) # CAO --> SAO
1526                KS = np.dot(sph2c_mat_pseudo, np.dot(KS, sph2c_mat_pseudo.T)) #SAO --> CAO
1527                
1528
1529            #### DIIS
1530            startDIIS = timer()
1531            diis_start_itr = 1
1532            if itr >= diis_start_itr:
1533                if not self.use_gpu:
1534                    with threadpool_limits(limits=ncores, user_api='blas'):
1535                        # print('DIIS ', controller.info())
1536                        KS = self.DIIS(S, dmat, KS)
1537                else:
1538                    KS = self.DIIS_cupy(S, dmat_cp, KS)
1539                    streams[0].synchronize()
1540                    cp.cuda.Stream.null.synchronize()
1541            durationDIIS = durationDIIS + timer() - startDIIS
1542
1543            #### Solve KS equation (Diagonalize KS matrix)
1544            startKS = timer()
1545            if self.use_gpu:
1546                eigvalues, eigvectors = self.solve_cupy(KS, S, orthogonalize=True) # Orthogonalization is necessary with CUDA
1547                mo_occ = self.getOcc_cupy(mol, eigvalues, eigvectors)
1548                dmat = self.gen_dm_cupy(eigvectors, mo_occ)
1549                dmat_cp = dmat
1550                dmat = cp.asnumpy(dmat)
1551                streams[0].synchronize()
1552                cp.cuda.Stream.null.synchronize()
1553            else:
1554                with threadpool_limits(limits=ncores, user_api='blas'):
1555                    # print('KS eigh', controller.info())
1556                    eigvalues, eigvectors = self.solve(KS, S, orthogonalize=orthogonalize, x=x)
1557                mo_occ = self.getOcc(mol, eigvalues, eigvectors)
1558                dmat = self.gen_dm(eigvectors, mo_occ)
1559            durationKS = durationKS + timer() - startKS
1560
1561            # Check when to switch to double precision for XC
1562            if self.use_gpu:
1563                if precision_XC is cp.float32:
1564                    if abs(Etot_new-Etot)/abs(Etot_new)<5e-7:
1565                        precision_XC = cp.float64
1566                        print('\nSwitching to double precision for XC evaluation after '+str(itr) +' iterations!', flush=True)
1567                        
1568
1569
1570            durationItr = timer() - startIter
1571            print('\n\nTime taken for the previous iteration: '+str(durationItr)+'\n\n', flush=True)
1572
1573            # Check convergence criteria
1574            if abs(Etot_new-Etot)<conv_crit:
1575                scf_converged = True
1576                print('\nSCF Converged after '+str(itr) +' iterations!', flush=True)
1577                Etot = Etot_new
1578                print('\n-------------------------------------', flush=True)
1579                print('Total Energy = ', Etot, flush=True)
1580                print('-------------------------------------\n\n', flush=True)
1581                break
1582
1583            Etot = Etot_new
1584            itr = itr + 1
1585            
1586
1587        if itr>=max_itr and not scf_converged:
1588            print('\nSCF NOT Converged after '+str(itr-1) +' iterations!', flush=True)
1589
1590
1591        durationSCF = timer() - startSCF
1592        # print(dmat)
1593        print('\nTime taken : '+str(durationSCF) +' seconds.', flush=True)
1594        print('\n\n', flush=True)
1595        print('-------------------------------------', flush=True)
1596        print('Profiling', flush=True)
1597        print('-------------------------------------', flush=True)
1598        print('Preprocessing                          ', durationXCpreprocessing + durationAO_values + durationgrids_prune_rho + durationSchwarz)
1599        if isDF:
1600            print('Density Fitting                        ', durationDF, flush=True)
1601            if DF_algo==6 or DF_algo==10:
1602                print('    DF (gamma)                         ', durationDF_gamma, flush=True)
1603                print('    DF (coeff)                         ', durationDF_coeff, flush=True)
1604                print('    DF (Jtri)                          ', durationDF_Jtri, flush=True)
1605                if cholesky:
1606                    print('    DF (Cholesky)                      ', durationDF_cholesky, flush=True)
1607        print('DIIS                                   ', durationDIIS, flush=True)
1608        print('KS matrix diagonalization              ', durationKS, flush=True)
1609        print('One electron Integrals (S, T, Vnuc)    ', duration1e, flush=True)
1610        if isDF:
1611            print('Coulomb Integrals (2c2e + 3c2e)        ', durationCoulomb-durationSchwarz-durationDF_cholesky, flush=True)
1612        if not isDF:
1613            print('Coulomb Integrals (4c2e)               ', durationCoulomb-durationSchwarz, flush=True)
1614        print('Grids construction                     ', durationgrids, flush=True)
1615        print('Exchange-Correlation Term              ', durationxc, flush=True)
1616        totalTime = durationXCpreprocessing + durationAO_values + duration1e + durationCoulomb - durationDF_cholesky + \
1617            durationgrids + durationxc + durationDF + durationKS + durationDIIS + durationgrids_prune_rho 
1618        print('Misc.                                  ', durationSCF - totalTime, flush=True)
1619        print('Complete SCF                           ', durationSCF, flush=True)
1620
1621        if self.use_gpu:
1622            # Free memory of all GPUs
1623            for igpu in range(self.n_gpus):
1624                cp.cuda.Device(igpu).use()
1625                cp._default_memory_pool.free_all_blocks()
1626
1627            # Switch back to main GPU
1628            cp.cuda.Device(0).use()
1629        return Etot, dmat

Perform Self-Consistent Field (SCF) calculation for Density Functional Theory (DFT).

This method implements a complete DFT SCF procedure including:

  • One-electron integral calculation (overlap, kinetic, nuclear attraction)
  • Two-electron integral calculation (4-center ERIs or density fitting)
  • Grid generation and pruning for exchange-correlation evaluation
  • Iterative SCF cycles with DIIS convergence acceleration
  • Exchange-correlation energy and potential evaluation using LibXC
  • GPU acceleration support for performance-critical operations

The implementation supports multiple algorithmic variants:

  • Density fitting (DF)
  • Schwarz screening for integral sparsity
  • Multiple XC evaluation algorithms (CPU/GPU optimized)
  • Dynamic precision switching for GPU calculations

SCF Procedure:

  1. Initialize one-electron integrals (S, T, V_nuc)
  2. Calculate/prepare two-electron integrals with optional screening
  3. Generate and prune integration grids for XC evaluation
  4. Iterative SCF loop:
  • Build Coulomb matrix J from density matrix
  • Evaluate exchange-correlation energy/potential on grids
  • Form Kohn-Sham matrix: H_KS = H_core + J + V_xc
  • Apply DIIS convergence acceleration
  • Diagonalize KS matrix to get new orbitals
  • Generate new density matrix from occupied orbitals
  • Check energy convergence
  1. Return converged total energy and density matrix

Computational Features:

  • Multi-threading support via Numba and configurable core count
  • GPU acceleration using CuPy for grid-based operations
  • Memory-efficient batched evaluation of XC terms
  • Multiple density fitting algorithms (DF_algo 1-10)
  • Basis function screening for XC evaluation efficiency
  • Optional Cholesky decomposition for 2-center integrals

Returns:

tuple[float, numpy.ndarray] Etot : float Converged total electronic energy in atomic units dmat : numpy.ndarray, shape (nbf, nbf) Converged density matrix in atomic orbital basis

Raises:

ConvergenceError If SCF fails to converge within max_itr iterations

Notes:

  • Uses class attributes for all computational parameters (basis, xc, conv_crit, etc.)
  • Extensive timing and profiling information printed during execution
  • Memory usage information displayed for large arrays
  • GPU memory automatically freed after completion
  • Supports both Cartesian (CAO) and Spherical (SAO) atomic orbital bases

The function performs comprehensive error checking and provides detailed timing breakdowns for performance analysis. GPU acceleration is automatically enabled when CuPy is available and use_gpu=True.

Example Energy Components:

  • Electron-nuclear attraction energy
  • Nuclear repulsion energy
  • Kinetic energy
  • Coulomb (electron-electron repulsion) energy
  • Exchange-correlation energy
